sections.title: Emergency dentistry
sections.body:
A dental emergency is any situation where pain, swelling, trauma, or infection needs prompt assessment.

Not all urgent dental problems look the same, and not all require the same response. Our role is to assess the situation, relieve pain where possible, and decide what treatment is needed to stabilise the problem safely.

If you are unsure whether your situation counts as an emergency, contacting the practice for advice is appropriate.
bullets: Assess what’s happening and how urgent it is
Settle pain and stabilise the problem safely
Explain the next step and the longer-term plan

sections.label: Introduction
sections.title: How we handle dental emergencies
sections.body:
If you are experiencing dental pain or swelling, contact the practice as soon as you can during opening hours so we can advise on the next steps.

We will ask about your symptoms and may offer advice, an urgent appointment, or referral depending on the situation. Outside normal hours, guidance will be provided on how to access appropriate care.

If swelling affects breathing, swallowing, or causes rapidly worsening symptoms, urgent medical attention may be required.

sections.title: Common reasons people contact us urgently
items: Severe toothache or pain that is worsening or disrupting sleep
Swelling of the gum, face, or jaw
A broken, cracked, or sharply chipped tooth
A crown, veneer, or filling that has come out and is painful or sharp
Dental trauma after an accident (loose, displaced, or knocked-out tooth)

sections.title: What to do right now
items: Contact us with a short description of what’s happened, where the pain is, and how long it has been going on
Use normal pain relief if safe for you (follow the packet guidance) and avoid chewing on the painful side
If you develop facial swelling, fever, difficulty swallowing, or breathing problems, seek urgent medical help

sections.label: Common emergency situations
sections.title: What you can expect at an emergency visit
sections.body:
We’ll focus on diagnosis and stabilisation.

That usually means an examination (and X-rays if needed), clear explanation of what we can see, and the least invasive step that reduces pain and risk. Sometimes that’s a temporary measure with a planned follow-up. Sometimes it’s a definitive repair — it depends on the tooth and the cause.

We’ll explain costs and options before anything starts, so you can make a clear decision under pressure.

sections.title: After an emergency visit
sections.body:
Following emergency care, further treatment may be recommended to address the underlying cause.

We’ll explain any findings clearly and discuss whether monitoring, further investigation, or planned treatment is appropriate.

You’ll have time to consider options once the immediate situation has settled.

sections.title: When urgent care may not be necessary

faqs.question: Is toothache an emergency?
faqs.answer: Toothache can have many causes. Some require urgent care, while others can be managed safely with advice and planned treatment.
